cess Safety Program Manager 
-Emergency Planning and Response: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-PSM Compliance Audits: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Trade Secrets: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager

 1.3 Prevention Program Elements

1.3.1 Process Safety Information
Process safety information (PSI) development, dissemination, and use is critical for the safe operation at this facility. Information regarding chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits are available for personnel to use in daily and strategic decision making. 
PSI was developed throughout the course of the Z-Star site project.  Accurate PSI will be maintained for the life of the facility.  The list below identifies the functional leaders responsible for maintaining the listed documentation.  

-Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) and/or other documents that include the following - Toxicity Information, Permissible Exposure Limits, Physical Property Data: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Process Flow Diagrams: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Process Chemistry: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Maximum Intended Inventory: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Safe Upper and Lower Limits: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Consequences of Deviation: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Materials of Construction: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs): Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Area Electrical Classification Drawings: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Relief System Design and Desi

The endpoint distance results for this ARS were generated by EPAs RMP*Comp program. The maximum estimated distance to the flammable endpoint of 1 psi overpressure was 0.1 miles. Using census data from MARPLOT, the estimated population is 0 within the WCS impact area based off the 2010 census.
Toxic Worst-Case Scenario
The amount of H2S onsite was evaluated and was determined to be less than the threshold quantities. Therefore, no toxic consequence modeling was performed for this facility

The Z-Star sites RMP level 3 prevention program is incorporated with the sites OSHA required Process Safety Program. Organization of the PSM/RMP program is depicted below:

Overall Responsibility for PSM/RMP Program at the Z-Star Site:
-PSM Element Sponsor: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager
-Employee Participation: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Process Safety Information: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Process Hazard Analysis: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Operating Procedures:	Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Training: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Contractors: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Pre-Startup Safety Review: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Mechanical Integrity: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Safe Work Practices (including Hot Work): Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Management of Change: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Incident Investigation:	Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Pro

recommendations are reviewed, and corresponding action items are developed. All actions are tracked and routinely reviewed by senior management.

REFERENCES

[2] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2003-A Process Hazard Analysis, 2022.

[7] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2017-A Management of Change, 2022.
[8] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2016-A Pre-Startup Safety Review, 2022.
[9] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2007-A Compliance Audits, 2022.
[10] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2019-A Incident Investigations, 2022.

[12] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2010-A Hot Work, 2022.
[13] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2012 Safe Work, 2022.
[14] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2011 Hot Work Burning and Welding, 2022.
[15] REV LNG, LLC, RNG-ALL-P2018-A Contractors, 2022.

o effectively prepare for all identified credible emergency scenarios. This is the official Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan for the Z-Star facility and supersedes previous plans and is intended to prevent Team Member actions which are not in accordance with the intent of this plan.

With respect to fires, the Z-Star site does not have a fire brigade and is therefore dependent upon the local Fire Department for response to fires that escalate beyond incipient phase.  Properly trained employees can respond to incipient fires requiring one fire extinguisher after notifying the local Fire Department.  The Z-Star site will work closely with the local Fire Department to prevent fires from occurring and to quickly mitigate fires should they occur.  
The Z-Star Emergency Response Plan (RNG-ALL-P2020-A Emergency Response) [16], will be reviewed to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC Team Members are trained on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan when initially hired, when the plan is revised, and when the Team Members responsibilities are changed.  All Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC Team Members will receive annual refresher training on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan.  In addition, contractors are trained on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan such that they understand alarms providing notification of potential emergency situations, how to appropriately respond to such situations, evacuation routes, and muster site locations.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Studies associated with prevention program elements such as PHAs, incident investigation, management of change, and compliance audits are regularly conducted at the Z-Star Site to verify designs and to identify potential hazards.  Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, review of industry experience, technology improvements, and employee suggestions.  Once formulated,

1.3.12 Contractors
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC s Contractor Safety Standard (RNG-ALL-P2018-A Contractors) [15], has been put in place to prevent injuries and illness as well as other safety and environmental incidents due to the activities of contractors working for Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC. The Contractor Safety Standard establishes minimum criteria for contractor Environmental, Health, Safety and Security (EHSS) management and provides guidance to Team Members who manage contractors to ensure safe completion of contracted work.

This standard applies to contractors performing work or seeking approval to perform work for Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC.  Vendors and other companies providing incidental services that do not influence processes or process equipment safety such as printer supply and servicing, vending machine supply and servicing, etc. are exempted from most of the requirements of this standard, except for orientation. Delivery and pick-up companies (e.g., UPS, FedEx, DHS, etc.) that provide delivery and pick-up services to a Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC owned or leased site are not included in the scope of this contractor standard.

1.4 Five-Year Accident History
The Commercial Plant that is being constructed at the Z-Star site is a new installation. As such there is no five-year accident history.  

1.5 Emergency Response Program
Overall safety at the Z-Star site is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC s Emergency Response Plan for the Z-Star site (RNG-ALL-P2020-A Emergency Response) [16], establishes policies and procedures and an organizational hierarchy for response to emergencies, including those involving releases of flammable liquids and gases occurring at the Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC location. This site level Emergency Plan guides the response of Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC Team Members and resources during an emergency and establishes requirements t

bout process safety, including: 
-Training sessions
-Regularly scheduled safety meetings
-Periodic departmental EHS and PSM audits
-Safe Work Permits
-Site Safety Committee meetings
-Roundtable meetings
-Toolbox talks
-PHA and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) sessions

1.3.11 Hot Work Permit
Controlling ignition sources is vital to Z-Star s release prevention program.  It is critical that personnel are notified when hot work is to be performed at the Z-Star site and that appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the hot work. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs  Hot Work Program Standard, (RNG-ALL-P2010-A Hot Work)  [12], Safe Work Standard (RNG-ALL-P2012 Safe Work) [13] , and Brazing and Welding Standards (RNG-ALL-P2011 Hot Work Burning and Welding) [14] establishes requirements for a safe hot work program, as required by OSHA 29CFR 1910.252, Welding, Cutting and Brazing; 29 CFR 1910.119 (k), Hot Work Permit; 29CFR1926.352, Fire Prevention, Welding and Cutting; and NFPA 51B, Standard for Fire Prevention During Welding, Cutting, and Other Hot Work. These requirements include the development of written procedures to prevent fires resulting from any temporary operation involving open flames or producing heat and/or sparks.  Hot Work activities include, but are not limited to welding, burning, grinding, chipping, brazing, soldering, thawing pipes, sand blasting, metal-on-metal contact or metal-on-concrete, internal combustion engines and other potentially spark producing equipment or activities, including static electrical discharges.  A Hot Work Permit is required when such work is to be performed outside of designated hot work areas and for operation of non-rated mobile equipment, power tools, spark or heat producing tools/equipment, and the use of battery powered devices in classified areas at the Z-Star site.  All hot work requires continuous monitoring, removal or protection of flammable/combustible materials and availability of fire extinguishers.

ed. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC will maintain copies of the last two audits on file.

1.3.9 Incident Investigation
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs Incident Investigation Standard, (RNG-ALL-P2019-A Incident Investigations) [10], establishes the requirements for reporting work related incidents and investigation of the incidents at Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC sites. Incidents may include, but are not limited to, injuries, illnesses, spills, releases, property or equipment damage, near misses, and security incidents involving personnel or property.
The Incident Investigation Standard defines the requirements for: 
-Initial Incident Reporting
-Initial Actions
-Incident Documentation and Follow-Up
-Incident Investigation
-Root Cause Analysis Evaluation
-Action Item Due Dates and Deadlines

1.3.10 Employee Participation
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs Employee Participation Standard (RNG-ALL-P2002-A Employee Participation) [12], establishes the Employee Participation (EP) program as required by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  This standard describes how Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs employees, including those at the Z-Star site, participate in each of the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP elements.  The EP program defined in this standard is intended to provide an environment that encourages the flow of information between management to employees and between employees to management to eliminate or mitigate the consequences of catastrophic releases of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace.  Specifically, the purpose of EP is to involve employees in the development of the PSM program and to ensure that all affected employees have access to the information developed under the PSM program to improve process safety throughout Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC.

In addition to committees, teams, and functions specifically established to address process safety issues, other plant activities offer employees the opportunity to participate in and relay concerns a

RNG, LLC facilities are safe for startup prior to the introduction of hazardous energy and/or chemicals. 

The scope of the standard includes PSSRs for greenfield facilities and new capital projects, for modifications documented as part of the MOC program, and for startups after turnaround and maintenance outages.  Conducting PSSRs minimizes the likelihood of safety or environmental impacts during and even after startups regardless of whether the process is covered by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard or EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  It is not applicable to corporate or other administrative offices and business-related changes.

1.3.8 Compliance Audit
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC ensures that the prevention program elements are functioning properly, complete, current, and applied in compliance with company policy, regulations, and good process safety practices as these are vital to the continuous improvement of the prevention program. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs  Compliance Audit Program (RNG-ALL-P2007-A Compliance Audits) [9] establishes the minimum requirements necessary to establish the ongoing effectiveness of applicable components of the Process Safety Management System via auditing.

This standard ensures the applicable components of the Process Safety Management System are functioning as intended at all manufacturing locations, including the Z-Star site, to outline the process for auditing each location, and to document the process for assessing and closing any gaps.  In addition, each element of Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC s PSM/RMP Program will be audited every 3 years to ensure that requirements of OSHAs PSM Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and EPAs RMP Program (40 CFR 68) are being met.  

Responsible managers must certify that they have evaluated their compliance with the provisions of OSHA PSM (29 CFR § 1910.119) and EPA RMP (40 CFR Part 68) to verify that the procedures and practices that have been developed are adequate and are being follow

eing adequately followed.

1.3.5 Mechanical Integrity
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs manages Mechanical Integrity following the Mechanical Integrity Standard (RNG-ALL-P2015-A Mechanical Integrity) [6].The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity (MI) Standard (RNG-ALL-P2015-A Mechanical Integrity) is to provide a summary and reference guide for Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC s MI Program. The MI program will track and mitigate risk for stationary process assets throughout Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC global facilities including those at the Z-Star site.  The MI Standard specifies the scope of the MI program and responsibilities for personnel. 

1.3.6 Management of Change
Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC manages change following the Management of Change (MOC) Standard (RNG-ALL-P2017-A Management of Change) [7]. This standard is to ensure that changes to Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs processes, other than Replacements-In-Kind (RIK), are made safely and in an environmentally responsible manner and are communicated to all affected personnel. This standard establishes how to initiate and implement changes to processes and the requirements therein. Changes to processes subject to this standard require documented review and authorization prior to implementation.

The MOC standard specifies changes that are subject to the standard, which includes, but not limited to, changes to processes, equipment, PSI, chemicals, quality, environmental aspects, and the organization.

1.3.7 Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)
A Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is a structured team effort in which personnel with various technical backgrounds review the status and condition of a process to ensure the process is safe to startup. Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC performs Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) at the Z-Star site following the Pre-Startup Safety Review Standard (RNG-ALL-P2016-A Pre-Startup Safety Review) [8], which establishes a means to verify that new or modified chemical and/or mechanical process operations at Zwemmer Z-Star

mpliance Training Standard (RNG-ALL-P2009-A Compliance Training) [5], defines how Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC trains personnel with respect to operating and maintaining processes. 
The Compliance Training Standard (RNG-ALL-P2009-A Compliance Training) [5], specifies, per OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard in 29 CFR 1910.119 Paragraph (g) and EPAs Risk Management Plant Rule in 40 CFR Part 68.71, that each employee involved in operating a PSM or RMP covered process must be trained in an overview of the process and in its operating procedures, receive refresher training at least every three years, and that such training will be appropriately documented.  Furthermore, the Compliance Training Standard (RNG-ALL-P2009-A Compliance Training) [5], specifies per OSHAs PSM Standard in 29 CFR 1910.119 Paragraph (j) and EPAs RMP Rule in 40 CFR Part 68.73, that employees involved in maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment in a PSM or RMP covered process must be trained in an overview of the process and its hazards and trained in the procedures applicable to the employees job tasks.

Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs  training program satisfies the requirements of OSHAs PSM standard and EPAs RMP rule and is comprised of the following: 
-Initial training
-Refresher training
-Process overview training
-Training provided as a result of management of change (MOC)
-Verification of understanding
-Training documentation

All operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment.  Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training.  Documentation of training is maintained by the Process Safety Program Manager.  Refresher training on the Training Standard itself shall be provided when conditions warrant, such as a major revision or if there are indications that Compliance Training Standard (RNG-ALL-P2009-A Compliance Training) [5]  is not b

vironmental procedures or requirements. 
--Any special or unique hazards.
-Safety Systems and their functions: 
--Critical / Emergency alarms and their set points including a description of corrective actions and consequences of remaining in alarm. 
--Safety interlocks descriptions including trip points and interlock actions.
--External detection and suppression systems descriptions for fire and releases of flammables.  
-Safe Operating Limits including: 
--Acceptable operating ranges and safety limits. 
--A table of consequences of deviation from safe operating limits on critical variables, guidance on potential causes, and steps to correct or avoid the deviation.   
-Steps for the following operating phases, as applicable: 
--Initial Startup 
--Normal Operations 
--Normal Shutdown 
--Temporary Operations 
--Emergency Operations should include the conditions that trigger a transition from normal operations to emergency operations.  An example would be sudden, but not complete, loss of a critical utility like steam. 
--Emergency Shutdown should include the conditions that trigger an emergency shutdown and the assignment of shutdown responsibilities to ensure that emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner. 
--Startup following an extended outage (turnaround) or emergency shutdown. 
All operating procedures shall be reviewed by someone certified in the process annually, or more frequently if required by local regulatory requirements, to ensure current operating practices are properly reflected. This annual review shall be documented including the date of the review and who completed the review. At least one reviewer must be a Team Member required to use the procedure.

1.3.4 Training 
The intent of Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLCs training program is to help employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process and facility operations and increase employee awareness with respect to the hazards particular to a process or facility. The Co

Is familiar with the documentation method.
-Is typically not the Project Manager or the MOC Owner.
-Is willing to capture the results in sufficient detail such that the analysis is clear to readers who are not present during the PHA discussions.

Any Team Members assigned the role of PHA scribe will be provided additional training to support the needed competencies.

1.3.3 Operating Procedure
Current, clearly written standard operating procedures and safe work practices help both experienced and inexperienced employees (including contract employees) respond in a safe, consistent, and prescribed manner. Operating Procedures Standard (RNG-ALL-P2006-A Operating Procedures) [4], specifies that written procedures/practices are developed, reviewed, implemented, and annually certified as reflective of current plant practice.

The procedure requires that operating procedures shall:
-Ensure each operating procedure has an owner, typically the Operations Manager. 
-Ensure the system of access for procedures is readily accessible to affected Team Members, i.e., to Team Members who work in or maintain a process.
-Ensure operating procedures are utilized each time the document is applicable unless indicated otherwise within the document. 
Elements within operating procedures include: 
-Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) considerations: 
--Hazard information from or references to applicable Safety Data Sheets (SDS). 
--Properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process. 
--PPE, engineering controls, administrative controls in place to prevent exposure. 
--Control measures to be taken if exposure occurs. 
--Descriptions of operational requirements necessary for the management of storm water, wastewater, air emissions, spills, waste, or any other environmental aspects potentially impacted by the execution of the procedure.  These requirements would be specific to the tasks covered in each procedure and are not intended to be used in lieu of site-wide en

.
-An estimate of the hours needed to complete the next PHA revalidation.

With respect to the date the next PHA revalidation must be completed, if the PHA is covered under OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP, this date must not be greater than 5 years from the date that the previous PHA was completed.  (OSHA PSM and EPA RMP require that PHAs for covered processes be revalidated at minimum every 5 years.)

1.3.2.2 PHA Team 
PHAs shall be performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, and the team shall include at least one employee who has experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated.
PHAs shall include one member of the team that is knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology being used.

PHA Core Team Members shall include: 
-The Operations Manager or designee.
-The Director of Engineering or designee.
-A Process Controls and Instrumentation Representative.  (This role may be fulfilled by the Director of Engineering or designee.)
-A qualified Operator or Supervisor that is knowledgeable and familiar with the process that is being evaluated.
-The Site EHS Manager or designee trained and knowledgeable in the PHA methodology that is being utilized.  (This role may be fulfilled by the Process Safety Program Manager, by the Director of EHS, or an external consultant.)

If any of the above named PHA Team Members is not available, the assigned Team Member may provide a deputy or other qualified designee to take their place.

PHA Auxiliary Team Members who may be called upon on an as needed basis include:
-Specific Subject Matter Expert (SME)  e.g., an external vendor who is an SME on the technology or the equipment under review
-Maintenance and Reliability Program Manager
-Maintenance Representative
-Environmental, Health, Safety Program Manager 

As a best practice, it is recommended that PHA Teams use a designated scribe to document PHAs.  A designated PHA scribe is someone that: 
-Is familiar with the PHA methodology being used.
-

e PHA methodology as needed.

All PHAs will address the following:
-The hazards of the process.
-Any previous incident with potential for catastrophic consequences in the workplace.
-Engineering/administrative controls related to hazards.
-Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls.
-Facility siting (the location of various components within the facility).
-Human factors.
-Qualitative evaluation of possible safety/health effects on employees stemming from control failures.

PHAs for MOCs (Management of Change) and Incident Investigation Follow-Up
When a change is made to a facility there can be safety and/or environmental ramifications.  Accordingly, it is often necessary to conduct a PHA as part of the MOC process.  
If an incident occurs, it is possible that a potential hazard scenario was not identified during the initial or revalidated PHA or that a safeguard listed in the existing PHA was not effective.  Accordingly, it is often necessary to conduct a PHA as follow-up to an Incident Investigation.
For PHAs at the Z-Star site that are conducted as part of MOC or as follow-up to an Incident Investigation, the existing PHA will be revised as needed or a new PHA using What If, Checklist, or What-If/Checklist methodology will be created to evaluate safety and environmental impacts.  If the item under consideration is part of a PSM covered process, the resulting PHA sessions shall become part of the existing PHA record with the MOC or Incident Investigation PHA being revalidated at the next 5-year revalidation interval.    

Revalidation Schedule
The Process Safety Program Manager shall create and maintain an up-to-date PHA Revalidation Schedule for the Z-Star site that contains the following information:
-Title of the PHA.
-Brief description of the scope of the PHA.
-Whether the PHA is covered under OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP.
-Date the previous PHA started.
-Date the previous PHA was completed.
-Proposed start date for the next PHA revalidation

ase
-To evaluate the likelihood and severity of potential scenarios
-To determine if existing safeguards (engineering and/or administrative controls) are adequate
-Where existing safeguards are inadequate, identify additional safeguards that should be considered 

Per OSHA/EPA PSM/RMP requirements, all initial PHAs/LOPAs will be conducted prior to facility startup and will be revalidated every 5 years.  In addition, to the extent possible, scheduling priority of future revalidation PHAs/LOPAs should be based on the extent of the process hazards, number of potentially affected employees, and age and operating history for the involved units.

When a PHA/LOPA team identifies a scenario for which existing safeguards are not adequate, an action item(s), also known as recommendation(s), to prevent, detect, or mitigate the scenario to reduce the risk to an acceptable level will be generated and assigned to the appropriate Team Member or Department.  In the context of PHAs/LOPAs recommendations are synonymous with action items.  All PHA/LOPA recommendations will be addressed and resolutions tracked.

1.3.2.1 PHA and LOPA Methodology
General
Initial PHAs and LOPAs for the Z-Star facility were conducted using a mixture of What-If, Checklist, What-If/Checklist, and Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodologies to determine and evaluate the hazards of the covered processes.  Future PHAs and LOPAs will also utilize acceptable PHA methodologies which include the following:
-What-If
-Checklist
-What-If/Checklist
-Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP)
-Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
-Fault Tree Analysis

The PHA and LOPA methodology used shall be appropriate for the complexity of the process. Typically, for new projects HAZOP or What-If PHA methodology is appropriate.  For PHAs conducted as part of the MOC process, typically What If, Checklist, or What-If/Checklist PHA methodology is appropriate.  The Process Safety Program Manager can provide guidance on appropriat

gn Basis: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Ventilation System Design: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Design Codes and Standards: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Material and Energy Balances: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager 
-Safety Systems: Director of Maintenance & Reliability or Process Safety Program Manager

PSI will be made available to affected personnel and to those compiling PSI as specified in RNG-ALL-P2001-A Process Safety Information [1].  If needed information is not immediately available, Team Members can request the information from their supervisor. Supervisors are responsible to fulfill reasonable requests for PSI.  Additional details regarding PSI can be found in RNG-ALL-P2001-A Process Safety Information [1].

1.3.2 Process Hazard Analysis
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Standard, (RNG-ALL-P2003-A Process hazard Analysis) [2] and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) Standard (RNG-ALL-P2005-A Layer of Protection Analysis) [3], establishes the program for assessing the hazards of covered process operations at the Z-Star Site.  By systematically examining each covered process and identifying the hazards associated with operation of the process, the Z-Star site has been able to plan for and will take appropriate actions to improve the safety of our employees, contractors, and visitors, the community, and the environment.

PHAs and LOPAs have been conducted for all process operations at the Z-Star facility covered by standards RNG-ALL-P2003-A Process hazard Analysis [2] and RNG-ALL-P2005-A Layer of Protection Analysis [3].  PHAs/LOPAs are conducted in a manner appropriate to the complexity of the process.  The objectives of the PHAs/LOPAs are the following:
-To identify the hazards of the process
-To identify credible human error and/or equipment failures that could lead to accidental rele

*Comp program was used to calculate the distance to an endpoint for the worst-case scenarios (WCS) and alternate release scenarios (ARS). MARPLOT was used to overlay the impact area on a map and estimate the population impacted within the endpoints of the WCS and ARS. 
The MARPLOT version 5.1.1 was used to produce the impact area overlays and estimate the population impacted, which uses 2010 census data. Comparing satellite imagery of area from 2010 to most recent satellite imagery of area from 2022  shows that there were minimal additional residential developments near the facility. Since the residential developments appear to be minor and no other sensitive receptors were added to this area, using the default 2010 census data provided by MARPLOT instead of the 2020 census data does not significantly affect the estimates for the impacted population. 

Flammable Worst-Case Scenario
One worst-case scenario (WCS) was developed for the Z-Star facility, as methane is present over the threshold quantities. 
The WCS was a vapor cloud explosion from an instantaneous release of the total contents of a single tanker storage vessel containing 22,000 lbs of methane. Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, should prevent or mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario.  The endpoint distance results for this WCS were generated by EPAs RMP*Comp program. The maximum estimated distance to the flammable endpoint of 1 psi overpressure was 0.2 miles. Using census data from MARPLOT, the estimated population is 0 within the WCS impact area based off the 2010 census.

Flammable Alternate Release Scenarios
The ARS associated with the release of a flammable substance at the Z-Star Site was a hose leak at the truck loading area containing 22,000 pounds of methane. For this scenario, the total amount released was considered 22,000 pounds of methane over 60 minutes.  Although there are numerous safe

methane in the trucks' tanker storage vessels and in the interconnected process, the commercial process at the Hayes site is covered by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule. The characteristics and hazards of methane are described in the following section (Section 1.2.3).

While the facility is not a part of the CAA Title V Operating Permit Program, the site has an air operating permit with Michigan State. The State Registration Number is P1205. 

1.2.3 Characteristics and Hazards of Methane and Safeguards Applied
Methane is a colorless and odorless gas or a liquid under pressure. It is used as a light source and fuel, and is the major gas present in Natural Gas and Renewable Natural Gas. Methane is flammable and an explosion hazard. Liquefied methane floats on water and boils. The vapor cloud produced is flammable. 

To minimize the potential for leakage of methane at Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC Z-Star site, inherently safe design, pressure relief systems, Basic Process Control System (BPCS) interlocks, Safety Instrumented System (SIS) interlocks, administrative controls, and extensive operator training have been included.  To minimize the potential for fire should methane leakage occur, flammable gas detectors have been located throughout process operations at Z-Star.  These flammable gas detectors have been equipped with alarms to the control room as well as local audible and visual alarms set at 10% of the lower explosive limit (LEL) to provide notification well before leakage reaches the flammable/explosive range.  In addition, where necessary, interlocks have been added to automatically take the process to a safe state should 40% of the LEL be reached.  Finally, flame detectors (fire-eyes) have been located throughout process operations to prevent catastrophic consequences.

1.2.4 Worst Case Scenario(s) and Alternative Release Scenario(s)
To perform the offsite consequence analysis for the Z-Star site, EPAs RMP

o conduct business with respect and care for the environment.  The safety, health, and environmental impact of any proposed modification at any REV site will be assessed to ensure that the site continues to operate in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.  In addition, all REV sites will be prepared for emergencies to ensure that in the unlikely event of an accidental release, employees and visitors at the site as well as the surrounding community are unharmed and the environment is protected.  

1.2	Description of the Z-Star Site, Site Processes, and Prioritization of EHS

1.2.1 Description of the Physical Site
The Z-Star Site is located at 4370 Limerick Rd in Caseville, Huron County, Michigan. It is located approximately 115 miles north of Detroit, Michigan and is adjacent to the Z-Star Dairy.  The Z-Star site is comprised of generally level terrain. Per FEMA Flood Insurance Rate Map 26063C0145D, this site is in Flood Zone X, an area outside the 100-year floodplain within an area of 0.2 percent annual chance of flood hazard.  

Highway access to the Z-Star site is convenient over national highways, state routes and county roads.  Access to this site will be from 53 (N Van Dyke Road) and W Kindle Rd. 


1.2.2 Description of Site Processes and Stationary Source
This site is a processing and loading facility with two (2) loading bays where raw biogas is treated and processed into RNG. The RNG is then compressed and transferred to truck tanker storage vessels. When the vessel is filled, it is transported via truck to an injection facility where the RNG is injected into a natural gas pipeline.. The RNG meets the same pipeline specification of fossil-based natural gas. The following process elements are used:  

-Digester Tank 
- Compressor 
- Heater 
- Filter 
- Pump

The Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC commercial process involves offloading of RNG from trucks into the natural gas pipeline. As commercial process operations at the Hayes site contain > 10,000 pounds of

1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1 Accidental Release Prevention, Emergency Response, and Commitment to EHS at the Z- Star RNG, LLC Site
The Z-Star site is operated by Zwemmer Z-Star RNG, LLC whos parent company is SJI RNG DevCo, LLC. SJI RNG DevCo, LLC is working with REV LNG, LLC (REV), who is a full-service supplier of Liquified Natural Gas (LNG), Compressed Natural Gas (CNG), and Renewable Natural Gas (RNG) based in Ulysses, Pennsylvania. Since the companys inception in 2013, REV has emerged as a leading provider of mobile gas solutions including transportation logistics, marine, mobile fuel solutions, and project development. Having safely sourced and delivered thousands of LNG loads to a variety of markets including Public Utilities, Renewable Gas projects, and Exploration and Production Companies, REV is focused on providing best-in-class turnkey mobile energy service with a focus on safety and environmental stewardship. 
REV specializes in the development and transportation of renewable natural gas (RNG), liquified natural gas (LNG) and compressed natural gas (CNG) in North America. Over the last few years, REV has become one of the countrys leading developers of RNG projects through capturing, cleaning and converting bio-methane to RNG. REV acquired the rights to build anaerobic digesters on dairy farms to produce RNG for injection into natural gas pipelines; REV then sources, supplies and transports RNG to utilities through ownership of mobile tankers, decompression and vaporization assets to ensure safe, firm and dependable service.
REV is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it operates.  Achieving consistently high production in manufacturing is not a goal, it is an outcome of the pursuit of safe and reliable operations.  REVs safety culture extends throughout the Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Program for the REV site.
